location: The same. A room in the palace.

lines.text: Enter, from one side, AARON, DEMETRIUS, and  CHIRON; from the other side, Young LUCIUS, and an  Attendant, with a bundle of weapons, and verses writ upon them

lines.speaker: chiron
lines.text: Demetrius, here's the son of Lucius; He hath some message to deliver us.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Ay, some mad message from his mad grandfather.

lines.speaker: young lucius
lines.text: My lords, with all the humbleness I may, I greet your honours from Andronicus. And pray the Roman gods confound you both!
Aside

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: Gramercy, lovely Lucius: what's the news?

lines.speaker: young lucius
lines.text: [Aside]  That you are both decipher'd, that's the news, For villains mark'd with rape.--May it please you, My grandsire, well advised, hath sent by me The goodliest weapons of his armoury To gratify your honourable youth, The hope of Rome; for so he bade me say; And so I do, and with his gifts present Your lordships, that, whenever you have need, You may be armed and appointed well: And so I leave you both: like bloody villains.
Aside
Exeunt Young LUCIUS, and Attendant

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: What's here? A scroll; and written round about? Let's see; 'Integer vitae, scelerisque purus, Non eget Mauri jaculis, nec arcu.'
Reads

lines.speaker: chiron
lines.text: O, 'tis a verse in Horace; I know it well: I read it in the grammar long ago.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Ay, just; a verse in Horace; right, you have it. Now, what a thing it is to be an ass! Here's no sound jest! the old man hath found their guilt; And sends them weapons wrapped about with lines, That wound, beyond their feeling, to the quick. But were our witty empress well afoot, She would applaud Andronicus' conceit: But let her rest in her unrest awhile. And now, young lords, was't not a happy star Led us to Rome, strangers, and more than so, Captives, to be advanced to this height? It did me good, before the palace gate To brave the tribune in his brother's hearing.
Aside

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: But me more good, to see so great a lord Basely insinuate and send us gifts.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Had he not reason, Lord Demetrius? Did you not use his daughter very friendly?

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: I would we had a thousand Roman dames At such a bay, by turn to serve our lust.

lines.speaker: chiron
lines.text: A charitable wish and full of love.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Here lacks but your mother for to say amen.

lines.speaker: chiron
lines.text: And that would she for twenty thousand more.

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: Come, let us go; and pray to all the gods For our beloved mother in her pains.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: [Aside]  Pray to the devils; the gods have given us over.
Trumpets sound within

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: Why do the emperor's trumpets flourish thus?

lines.speaker: chiron
lines.text: Belike, for joy the emperor hath a son.

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: Soft! who comes here?
Enter a Nurse, with a blackamoor Child in her arms

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: Good morr ow, lords: O, tell me, did you see Aaron the Moor?

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Well, more or less, or ne'er a whit at all, Here Aaron is; and what with Aaron now?

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: O gentle Aaron, we are all undone! Now help, or woe betide thee evermore!

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Why, what a caterwauling dost thou keep! What dost thou wrap and fumble in thine arms?

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: O, that which I would hide from heaven's eye, Our empress' shame, and stately Rome's disgrace! She is deliver'd, lords; she is deliver'd.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: To whom?

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: I mean, she is brought a-bed.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Well, God give her good rest! What hath he sent her?

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: A devil.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Why, then she is the devil's dam; a joyful issue.

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: A joyless, dismal, black, and sorrowful issue: Here is the babe, as loathsome as a toad Amongst the fairest breeders of our clime: The empress sends it thee, thy stamp, thy seal, And bids thee christen it with thy dagger's point.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: 'Zounds, ye whore! is black so base a hue? Sweet blowse, you are a beauteous blossom, sure.

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: Villain, what hast thou done?

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: That which thou canst not undo.

lines.speaker: chiron
lines.text: Thou hast undone our mother.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Villain, I have done thy mother.

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: And therein, hellish dog, thou hast undone. Woe to her chance, and damn'd her loathed choice! Accursed the offspring of so foul a fiend!

lines.speaker: chiron
lines.text: It shall not live.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: It shall not die.

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: Aaron, it must; the mother wills it so.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: What, must it, nurse? then let no man but I Do execution on my flesh and blood.

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: I'll broach the tadpole on my rapier's point: Nurse, give it me; my sword shall soon dispatch it.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Sooner this sword shall plough thy bowels up. Stay, murderous villains! will you kill your brother? Now, by the burning tapers of the sky, That shone so brightly when this boy was got, He dies upon my scimitar's sharp point That touches this my first-born son and heir! I tell you, younglings, not Enceladus, With all his threatening band of Typhon's brood, Nor great Alcides, nor the god of war, Shall seize this prey out of his father's hands. What, what, ye sanguine, shallow-hearted boys! Ye white-limed walls! ye alehouse painted signs! Coal-black is better than another hue, In that it scorns to bear another hue; For all the water in the ocean Can never turn the swan's black legs to white, Although she lave them hourly in the flood. Tell the empress from me, I am of age To keep mine own, excuse it how she can.
Takes the Child from the Nurse, and draws

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: Wilt thou betray thy noble mistress thus?

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: My mistress is my mistress; this myself, The vigour and the picture of my youth: This before all the world do I prefer; This maugre all the world will I keep safe, Or some of you shall smoke for it in Rome.

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: By this our mother is forever shamed.

lines.speaker: chiron
lines.text: Rome will despise her for this foul escape.

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: The emperor, in his rage, will doom her death.

lines.speaker: chiron
lines.text: I blush to think upon this ignomy.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Why, there's the privilege your beauty bears: Fie, treacherous hue, that will betray with blushing The close enacts and counsels of the heart! Here's a young lad framed of another leer: Look, how the black slave smiles upon the father, As who should say 'Old lad, I am thine own.' He is your brother, lords, sensibly fed Of that self-blood that first gave life to you, And from that womb where you imprison'd were He is enfranchised and come to light: Nay, he is your brother by the surer side, Although my seal be stamped in his face.

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: Aaron, what shall I say unto the empress?

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: Advise thee, Aaron, what is to be done, And we will all subscribe to thy advice: Save thou the child, so we may all be safe.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Then sit we down, and let us all consult. My son and I will have the wind of you: Keep there: now talk at pleasure of your safety.
They sit

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: How many women saw this child of his?

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Why, so, brave lords! when we join in league, I am a lamb: but if you brave the Moor, The chafed boar, the mountain lioness, The ocean swells not so as Aaron storms. But say, again; how many saw the child?

lines.speaker: nurse
lines.text: Cornelia the midwife and myself; And no one else but the deliver'd empress.

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: The empress, the midwife, and yourself: Two may keep counsel when the third's away: Go to the empress, tell her this I said. Weke, weke! so cries a pig prepared to the spit.
He kills the nurse

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: What mean'st thou, Aaron? wherefore didst thou this?

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: O Lord, sir, 'tis a deed of policy: Shall she live to betray this guilt of ours, A long-tongued babbling gossip? no, lords, no: And now be it known to you my full intent. Not far, one Muli lives, my countryman; His wife but yesternight was brought to bed; His child is like to her, fair as you are: Go pack with him, and give the mother gold, And tell them both the circumstance of all; And how by this their child shall be advanced, And be received for the emperor's heir, And substituted in the place of mine, To calm this tempest whirling in the court; And let the emperor dandle him for his own. Hark ye, lords; ye see I have given her physic, And you must needs bestow her funeral; The fields are near, and you are gallant grooms: This done, see that you take no longer days, But send the midwife presently to me. The midwife and the nurse well made away, Then let the ladies tattle what they please.
Pointing to the nurse

lines.speaker: chiron
lines.text: Aaron, I see thou wilt not trust the air With secrets.

lines.speaker: demetrius
lines.text: For this care of Tamora, Herself and hers are highly bound to thee.
Exeunt DEMETRIUS and CHIRON bearing off the Nurse's body

lines.speaker: aaron
lines.text: Now to the Goths, as swift as swallow flies; There to dispose this treasure in mine arms, And secretly to greet the empress' friends. Come on, you thick lipp'd slave, I'll bear you hence; For it is you that puts us to our shifts: I'll make you feed on berries and on roots, And feed on curds and whey, and suck the goat, And cabin in a cave, and bring you up To be a warrior, and command a camp.
Exit
